response:
In India, the President of India presides over the joint sessions of Parliament. The President is the head of the state and the ceremonial head of the government, and is elected by the members of the Electoral College, which consists of the elected members of both houses of Parliament and the state legislatures.

When a joint session of Parliament is convened, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha (the lower house of Parliament) and the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of Parliament) jointly preside over the proceedings. However, in the event of a tie, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha has the casting vote.

The joint session of Parliament is convened by the President under Article 108 of the Constitution, which states that the President may summon a joint session of both houses of Parliament to consider a bill or any other matter that he thinks is of national importance. The President may also address the joint session and give his views on the matter being considered.

During the joint session, the members of both houses of Parliament sit together in the Central Hall of Parliament House, and the proceedings are conducted by the Speaker of the Lok Sabha. The members of the Rajya Sabha also participate in the proceedings, but they do not have the power to vote. The joint session is usually convened to pass important legislation or to discuss matters of national importance.
triplets: elected members of both houses of Parliament
joint session of both houses of Parliament
any other matter of national importance
members of both houses of Parliament
reference: The Parliament of India is bicameral . Concurrence of both houses are required to pass any bill . However , the authors of the Constitution of India visualised situations of deadlock between the upper house i.e. Rajya Sabha and the lower house i.e. Lok Sabha . Therefore , the Constitution of India provides for Joint sittings of both the Houses to break this deadlock . The joint sitting of the Parliament is called by the President and is presided over by the Speaker or , in his absence , by the Deputy Speaker of the Lok Sabha or in his absence , the Deputy - Chairman of the Rajya Sabha . If any of the above officers are not present then any other member of the Parliament can preside by consensus of both the House .

Two fibers made of proteins are:

1. Keratin - a protein fiber found in skin, hair, and nails.
2. Silk - a protein fiber produced by silkworms and used to make silk fabrics.
reference: Animal fibers are natural fibers that consist largely of particular proteins . Instances are silk , hair / fur ( including wool ) and feathers . The animal fibers used most commonly both in the manufacturing world as well as by the hand spinners are wool from domestic sheep and silk . Also very popular are alpaca fiber and mohair from Angora goats . Unusual fibers such as Angora wool from rabbits and Chiengora from dogs also exist , but are rarely used for mass production .

The term "Parsons nose" is a colloquialism used in the United Kingdom and Ireland to refer to the upturned nose of a bird, particularly a bird of prey. The term is derived from the name of a famous English ornithologist, Frank Parsons, who was known for his distinctive upturned nose.

Parsons was a well-known birdwatcher and naturalist who lived in the early 20th century. He was particularly interested in birds of prey, and his passion for these birds led him to become a prominent figure in the field of ornithology.

Over time, Parsons' distinctive nose became a recognizable feature among birdwatchers and naturalists, and it became a sort of inside joke among them to refer to the upturned nose of a bird as a "Parsons nose." The term has since become widely used in the United Kingdom and Ireland, and is often used in birdwatching circles to describe the distinctive nose of a bird of prey.

It's worth noting that the term "Parsons nose" is not a formal scientific term, but rather a colloquialism that has been adopted by birdwatchers and naturalists as a way of describing a distinctive feature of certain birds.

the upturned nose of a bird of prey

reference: The phrase `` parson 's nose '' comes from the notion that an English parson may ' have his nose up in the air ' , upturned like the chicken 's rear end . The term must have been known as early as around 1400 AD , when a carpenter had been contracted to provide new choir stalls for St Mary 's Church , Nantwich . The vicar was either slow to pay the artisan , or did not pay at all . In retaliation , on the last misericord in the stalls , the carpenter carved a bird with an image of that Vicar 's face with protuberant nose as rump . The carving is still visible today .

The first recorded use of an electric guitar was by jazz guitarist Charlie Christian, who recorded with the Benny Goodman Sextet in 1939. Christian was a member of the band and played a Gibson ES-150, which was one of the first commercially produced electric guitars.

The recording, which took place on August 1, 1939, was of a song called "Flying Home," and it featured Christian's electric guitar playing a solo and providing rhythm accompaniment. The recording was released as a 78 rpm record and became a hit, helping to popularize the electric guitar as a jazz instrument.

It's worth noting that there were other musicians who experimented with electric guitars before Christian, but his recording with the Benny Goodman Sextet is generally considered to be the first commercial recording featuring an electric guitar.

reference: George Warren Barnes ( July 17 , 1921 -- September 5 , 1977 ) was an American swing jazz guitarist who played the first electric guitar in 1931 . He made the first commercial recording of an electric guitar on March 1 , 1938 , in sessions with Big Bill Broonzy .

The first series premiered on BBC Two on 8 January 1999 and lasted for six episodes , concluding on 12 February 1999 . A second series commenced on 14 January 2000 and finished on 18 February 2000 , again including six episodes . A short sketch included as part of Comic Relief was broadcast on 16 March 2001 . Due to the high viewing figures and success the show received , it was moved to BBC One for a six - episode third series which was the last . Each episode was written by Jonathan Harvey and directed by Liddy Oldroyd for the first two series and the special ; the third series was directed by Tristram Shapeero .

The last name Waters is of English origin and is derived from the Old English word "wæter," which means "water." It is believed to have originated as a topographic name for someone who lived near a body of water, such as a river, lake, or sea. It may also have been used to describe a person who worked as a waterman, such as a ferryman or a fisherman.

In some cases, the surname Waters may also be an anglicized form of the Gaelic surname MacUisce, which means "son of the water." This surname was commonly found in Ireland and Scotland, where it was used to describe a person who lived near a river or stream.

The use of the surname Waters can be traced back to the Middle Ages in England, where it was first found in the counties of Yorkshire, Lincolnshire, and Norfolk. It has since spread to other parts of the world, including the United States, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand.

Some notable people with the surname Waters include:

* Roger Waters, British musician and songwriter, best known as a member of the rock band Pink Floyd
* Ethel Waters, American singer and actress, known for her performances in the 1920s and 1930s
* Muddy Waters, American blues musician,

response:
The raid on the Harpers Ferry Arsenal was led by John Brown, a prominent abolitionist who believed that violence was necessary to end slavery. Brown and his followers, including several of his sons, launched the raid on October 16, 1859, with the goal of seizing the federal armory and distributing weapons to local slaves, who would then rise up and overthrow their masters.

The raid was not successful, and Brown and his men were quickly surrounded by a company of U.S. Marines led by Colonel Robert E. Lee, who had been sent to suppress the uprising. After a brief battle, Brown and his surviving followers were captured and later executed for treason, conspiracy, and murder.

The raid on Harpers Ferry was a significant event in the lead-up to the Civil War, as it heightened tensions between abolitionists and pro-slavery forces and helped to galvanize public opinion against slavery. Brown's actions were seen by many as a heroic attempt to end the evil of slavery, and he became a martyr for the abolitionist cause.

violence was necessary to end slavery
seizing the federal armory and distributing weapons to local slaves
rise up and overthrow their masters

were later executed for treason, conspiracy, and murder

reference: John Brown 's raid on Harper 's Ferry ( also known as John Brown 's raid or The raid on Harper 's Ferry ) was an effort by armed abolitionist John Brown to initiate an armed slave revolt in 1859 by taking over a United States arsenal at Harpers Ferry , Virginia . Brown 's party of 22 was defeated by a company of U.S. Marines , led by First Lieutenant Israel Greene . Colonel Robert E. Lee was in overall command of the operation to retake the arsenal . John Brown had originally asked Harriet Tubman and Frederick Douglass , both of whom he had met in his transformative years as an abolitionist in Springfield , Massachusetts , to join him in his raid , but Tubman was prevented by illness and Douglass declined , as he believed Brown 's plan would fail .

response: The longest pier in the UK is the Southend Pier in Southend-on-Sea, Essex. It stretches for 1.34 miles (2.16 km) into the Thames Estuary and has been in operation since 1830. The pier was originally built as a landing stage for steamboats, but it has been extended and rebuilt several times over the years. Today, it is a popular tourist attraction and offers stunning views of the estuary and the surrounding coastline. The pier is also home to a number of amusement arcades, gift shops, and restaurants.
reference: Southend Pier is a major landmark in Southend - on - Sea . Extending 1.34 miles ( 2.16 km ) into the Thames Estuary , it is the longest pleasure pier in the world . Sir John Betjeman once said that `` the Pier is Southend , Southend is the Pier '' . The pier is a Grade II listed building .

The oldest known recording of "House of the Rising Sun" is a 1933 version by the singer and guitarist Clarence "Tom" Ashley, who recorded it for the Library of Congress's Archive of American Folk Song. Ashley's version is considered to be one of the earliest known recordings of the song, and it is a prime example of the traditional Appalachian folk music style in which the song was originally performed.

Ashley's recording of "House of the Rising Sun" features his distinctive, high-pitched vocals and a simple, repetitive guitar accompaniment. The song's lyrics are similar to those of later versions, but they have a few notable differences, such as the line "I'm going to the river, if I never return" instead of "I'm going to the river, and I'll never return."

The recording was made in a field session, meaning that it was recorded outside of a formal studio setting, and it has a raw, unpolished quality that reflects the song's folk roots. Despite its age, Ashley's version of "House of the Rising Sun" remains a powerful and haunting rendition of the song, and it continues to be celebrated as a classic of American folk music.

reference: The oldest known recording of the song , under the title `` Rising Sun Blues '' , is by Appalachian artists Clarence `` Tom '' Ashley and Gwen Foster , who recorded it for Vocalion Records on September 6 , 1933 . Ashley said he had learned it from his grandfather , Enoch Ashley . Roy Acuff , an `` early - day friend and apprentice '' of Ashley 's , learned it from him and recorded it as `` Rising Sun '' on November 3 , 1938 . Several older blues recordings of songs with similar titles are unrelated , for example , `` Rising Sun Blues '' by Ivy Smith ( 1927 ) and `` The Risin ' Sun '' by Texas Alexander ( 1928 ) .

1. CCTV (Closed-Circuit Television): CCTV was invented in the 1940s by a team of engineers at the BBC (British Broadcasting Corporation). They developed a system that could transmit live images from a camera to a monitor, which was initially used for internal communication and monitoring purposes within the BBC. This technology laid the foundation for modern CCTV systems used in home security.
2. Video Door Phones: The first video door phone was invented in the 1960s by a Japanese company, Panasonic (then known as Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.). This system allowed homeowners to see and communicate with visitors at their door via a camera and intercom.
3. Home Security Systems: In the 1970s and 1980s, home security systems started to become more sophisticated, incorporating features like motion detectors, door and window sensors, and alarm systems. Companies like ADT (American District Telegraph) and Brinks Home Security were among the early providers of these systems.

response: The Greek god who flew too close to the sun is Icarus. Icarus was the son of the inventor Daedalus, who created wings made of feathers and wax for himself and his son. Despite his father's warnings, Icarus flew higher and higher, becoming more and more reckless. He eventually flew too close to the sun, causing his wings to melt and resulting in his fall to his death in the sea. This myth serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of hubris and the importance of heeding advice.

wings made of feathers and wax
Icarus flying too close to the sun
his fall to his death in the sea
reference: In Greek mythology , Icarus ( the Latin spelling , conventionally adopted in English ; Ancient Greek : Ἴκαρος , Íkaros , Etruscan : Vikare ) is the son of the master craftsman Daedalus , the creator of the Labyrinth . Often depicted in art , Icarus and his father attempt to escape from Crete by means of wings that his father constructed from feathers and wax . Icarus ' father warns him first of complacency and then of hubris , asking that he fly neither too low nor too high , so the sea 's dampness would not clog his wings or the sun 's heat melt them . Icarus ignored his father 's instructions not to fly too close to the sun ; when the wax in his wings melted he tumbled out of the sky and fell into the sea where he drowned .

reference: Stephanie Judith Tanner ( portrayed by Jodie Sweetin ) is the witty , sarcastic middle child of Danny and Pam , the younger sister of D.J. , and the older sister of Michelle . Her mother died when she was five years old . Her catchphrases during the early seasons of the series include `` how rude ! , '' `` well , pin a rose on your nose ! '' and `` hot dog '' . She eventually evolved into something of a tomboy in seasons four and five . Stephanie has a habit of spying on D.J. 's life by reading her diary and eavesdropping on her telephone calls ( having been caught in the act several times ) , and is generally the most athletic and nosiest of the Tanner girls . Her best friends in school are Gia Mahan and Mickey , whom she meets in season seven ( the former is the only one who appears through to season eight ) . Of the three sisters , Stephanie has dealt with the toughest issues , such as peer pressure into smoking ( in season seven 's `` Fast Friends '' ) , `` make - out '' parties ( in season eight 's `` Making Out is Hard to Do '' ) , joyriding ( in season eight 's `` Stephanie 's Wild Ride '' ) , and uncovering a classmate 's child abuse ( in season six 's `` Silence is Not Golden '' ) , as well as the death of her mother when she was only five . In her early years , she is very sentimental about Mr. Bear , a stuffed animal that her mother gave to her after Michelle was born ( this was the focal point of the season two episode `` Goodbye Mr. Bear '' ) . She and Jesse are the most abrasive when it comes to how they feel about Kimmy Gibbler .

reference: Peter Andrew Beardsley MBE ( born 18 January 1961 ) is an English former footballer who played as a forward or midfielder between 1979 and 1999 . In 1987 , he set a record transfer fee in the English game and represented his country 59 times between 1986 and 1996 , once as captain , taking part in two FIFA World Cups ( 1986 and 1990 ) and UEFA Euro 1988 . At club level , he played for Newcastle United , Liverpool and Everton , having also had spells with Carlisle United , Manchester United , Vancouver Whitecaps , Bolton Wanderers , Manchester City , Fulham , Hartlepool United and the Melbourne Knights . He was briefly appointed as the caretaker manager of Newcastle United in 2010 .

Bacteroides are a group of bacteria that are commonly found in the human gut microbiome, as well as in the guts of other animals. They are also found in soil, sediments, and marine environments.

In the human body, Bacteroides are found in the colon and rectum, where they play a role in the breakdown and fermentation of complex polysaccharides, such as cellulose and pectin, which are found in plant-based foods. They produce short-chain fatty acids, such as acetate and butyrate, which are used by the body for energy and also help to maintain the health of the colonic epithelium.

In the environment, Bacteroides can be found in a variety of habitats, including:

1. Soil: Bacteroides are abundant in soil, where they contribute to the decomposition of organic matter and the cycling of nutrients.
2. Sediments: Bacteroides can also be found in aquatic sediments, where they play a role in the degradation of organic matter and the cycling of nutrients.
3. Marine environments: Bacteroides are also found in marine environments, such as in the guts of marine animals, and in sea water.

reference: Bacteroides fragilis is an obligately anaerobic , Gram - negative , rod - shaped bacterium . It is part of the normal flora of the human colon and is generally commensal , but can cause infection if displaced into the bloodstream or surrounding tissue following surgery , disease , or trauma .
